description: From dis- +â€Ž order. Middle English disordeine, from Old French desordainer, from Medieval Latin disordinare.

entries.meaning: Absence of order; state of not being arranged in an orderly manner.
examples: After playing the children left the room in disorder.

entries.meaning: A disturbance of civic peace or of public order.
examples: The class was thrown into disorder when the teacher left the room
The army tried to prevent disorder when claims the elections had been rigged grew stronger.

entries.meaning: (medicine, countable) A physical or mental malfunction.

verbs.description: disorder (third-person singular simple present disorders, present participle disordering, simple past and past participle disordered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To throw into a state of disorder.
(transitive) To knock out of order or sequence.
